osha.title: OSHA 1910.178 ‚Äî Pre-Operation Requirements
bullets: Inspect the truck before each shift and remove from service if any condition adversely affects safety (29 CFR 1910.178(q)). Only authorized personnel perform repairs.
PPE & seat belt: Wear required PPE (hi-vis vest, hard hat, eye/ear protection, safety boots) and use the seat belt.
Data plate: Present, legible, and reflects all attachments; know capacity and load center.
Controls & alerts: Test horn, lights/beacon, reverse beeper, and alarms; sound horn at blind corners and intersections.
Forks, chains, hoses: Matched forks, pins in place, no cracks/bends; chains lubricated with no kinks/broken links; hoses/cylinders free of leaks.
Brakes & steering: Service brake, parking brake, and steering respond correctly.
Tires & wheels: Adequate tread/inflation, no cuts/chunks; lugs tight; rims undamaged.
Housekeeping: Keep aisles clear; clean or barricade spills promptly.
Tag out unsafe trucks: Report defects; do not operate until repaired and verified safe.

osha.title: OSHA Basics ‚Äî 8-Point Inspection
bullets: Run the full inspection each shift and record defects. Remove trucks from service if any condition adversely affects safety (29 CFR 1910.178(q)(7)). Repairs must be by authorized personnel.
Forks: No cracks or bends; matched pair; lock pins in place; heel wear within limit.
Chains & hoses: No kinks, tight/broken links, frays, or leaks; proper tension/lube; guards in place.
Tires & wheels: Adequate tread/inflation (pneumatic); no chunks/splits; lugs tight; rims undamaged.
Horn & lights: Horn works (use at blind corners); head/taillights, beacon, and reverse beeper functional.
Seat belt & data plate: Seat belt present/working; data plate present, legible, and matches attachments/capacity.
Leaks/undercarriage: No hydraulic, fuel, or coolant leaks; mast/undercarriage clear; clean spills per procedure.
Battery/LP system: Cables/connectors intact and secure; charger leads OK; LP cylinder secured, no leaks/odor.
Safety devices: Parking brake, deadman, brakes, and steering respond correctly; alarms present and working.

osha.title: OSHA Basics ‚Äî Balance & Load Handling
bullets: Capacity & attachments: Never exceed nameplate capacity; attachments change capacity and load center‚Äîuse the data plate.
Keep load low & tilted back: Travel with forks ~4‚Äì6 in (10‚Äì15 cm) off the floor; mast slightly back; avoid sudden starts/stops/turns.
Stability triangle: Keep the combined center of gravity inside the triangle; slow at corners and uneven surfaces; no riders and keep body inside the compartment.
Visibility: Maintain a clear view; if the load blocks view, travel in reverse when safe or use a spotter.
Grades/ramps: With a load, drive upgrade; without a load, drive downgrade. Do not turn on ramps; forks low and tilted back; descend slowly.
Stacking/unstacking: Stop; set parking brake; square mast; level forks; lift/lower smoothly; do not raise or lower while moving.
Pedestrians: Sound horn at intersections; make eye contact; maintain safe separation; pedestrians have right-of-way.

checklist_items.title: Capacity & attachments
checklist_items.description: Never exceed nameplate capacity; attachments change capacity and load center‚Äîuse the data plate.

details.heading: Understanding Load Capacity:
details.body: The data plate shows maximum capacity at a specific load center (usually 24 inches). If your load's center of gravity is farther away, capacity decreases significantly.

subsections.heading: Attachment Impact on Capacity:
items: Attachments add weight to the front of the truck
This shifts the combined center of gravity forward
Available lifting capacity is reduced by attachment weight PLUS additional derating
Always check the attachment data plate for new capacity limits

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Operating beyond capacity is a leading cause of tip-overs and fatalities. Always verify before lifting.

checklist_items.title: Keep load low & tilted back
checklist_items.description: Travel with forks ~4‚Äì6 in (10‚Äì15 cm) off the floor; mast slightly back; avoid sudden starts/stops/turns.

details.heading: Proper Travel Position (OSHA 1910.178(n)(6)):
items: Fork height: 4-6 inches (10-15 cm) above ground clears obstacles but maintains low center of gravity
Mast tilt: Tilt mast back slightly to secure load and prevent sliding forward
Load against backrest: Keep load tight against load backrest extension

subsections.heading: Why This Matters:
subsections.body: A raised load dramatically raises the combined center of gravity, making the forklift unstable. Sudden movements (starts, stops, turns) shift weight and can cause tip-overs even with stable loads.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Traveling with elevated loads is prohibited except during stacking operations. Always lower forks before moving.

checklist_items.title: Stability triangle
checklist_items.description: Keep the combined center of gravity inside the triangle; slow at corners and uneven surfaces; no riders and keep body inside the compartment.

details.heading: The Stability Triangle:
details.body: Three-wheel forklifts have a triangular stability zone formed by the two front wheels and the pivot point of the rear wheel. Four-wheel forklifts have a rectangular zone but the concept is similar.

subsections.heading: Center of Gravity Rules:
items: Empty truck: COG is within the triangle
With load: Combined COG shifts forward toward the load
Turning: COG shifts to the outside of the turn
Elevated load: COG rises, reducing stability

subsections.heading: Maintaining Stability:
subsections.body: Slow down when turning, especially with loads. Avoid turning on slopes or uneven surfaces. Never carry riders - extra weight destabilizes the truck. Always keep your body inside the operator compartment and overhead guard.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è If the combined COG moves outside the stability zone, the forklift will tip over. No exceptions.

checklist_items.title: Visibility
checklist_items.description: Maintain a clear view; if the load blocks view, travel in reverse when safe or use a spotter.

details.heading: Visibility Requirements (OSHA 1910.178(n)(6)):
details.body: Operators must have a clear view of the travel path at all times. When the load obstructs forward visibility:
items: Option 1: Travel in reverse (forks trailing) with frequent looks ahead
Option 2: Use a spotter to guide you (maintain constant communication)
Never: Travel blind or rely solely on memory of the path

subsections.heading: Additional Visibility Considerations:
items: Keep mast upright when traveling to maximize sight lines
Use mirrors to check blind spots
Ensure adequate lighting in work areas
Sound horn at intersections even if you think you can see

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Most collisions occur when operators can't see pedestrians or obstacles. Never guess - always verify clear path.

checklist_items.title: Grades/ramps
checklist_items.description: With a load, drive upgrade; without a load, drive downgrade. Do not turn on ramps; forks low and tilted back; descend slowly.

details.heading: Grade and Ramp Safety (OSHA 1910.178(n)(7)):

subsections.heading: The Golden Rule:
items: Loaded: Forks pointing UPHILL (prevents load from sliding forward)
Unloaded: Forks pointing DOWNHILL (keeps forklift stable)

subsections.heading: Critical Grade Procedures:
items: Keep forks 4-6 inches off surface with mast tilted back
NEVER turn on a ramp or slope - tip-over risk is extreme
Control speed - descend slowly using brakes, not momentum
Watch for slippery conditions (water, ice, oil)
Use chocks when loading/unloading on grades

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Turning on a ramp is one of the most dangerous forklift maneuvers. Always straighten out before changing direction.

checklist_items.title: Stacking/unstacking
checklist_items.description: Stop; set parking brake; square mast; level forks; lift/lower smoothly; do not raise or lower while moving.

details.heading: Safe Stacking Procedure (OSHA 1910.178(o)(2)):

subsections.heading: Before lifting:
items: Come to complete stop
Set parking brake
Square the mast (vertical)
Level the forks (equal height)
Position forks fully under load

subsections.heading: During lifting:
items: Lift smoothly - no jerking motions
Tilt mast back slightly once load clears rack
Never raise or lower loads while the truck is moving
Watch for overhead obstructions

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Lifting while moving or jerky hydraulic movements can cause loads to shift or fall. Always stop completely before raising/lowering.

checklist_items.title: Pedestrians
checklist_items.description: Sound horn at intersections; make eye contact; maintain safe separation; pedestrians have right-of-way.

details.heading: Pedestrian Safety Priority (OSHA 1910.178(n)(4)):
details.body: Pedestrians ALWAYS have the right of way. The forklift operator is responsible for avoiding pedestrian contact under all circumstances.

subsections.heading: Safe Pedestrian Practices:
items: Sound horn: At ALL intersections, blind corners, doorways, and when approaching pedestrians
Eye contact: Make direct eye contact before passing near anyone
Safe distance: Maintain at least 3 feet of clearance when passing
Spotter required: When visibility is limited or in congested areas
Stop if uncertain: If you can't confirm it's safe, stop and wait

subsections.heading: Common Pedestrian Hazards:
subsections.body: Workers wearing headphones, backing out of aisles, focused on tasks, or crossing at non-designated points. Never assume pedestrians see or hear you.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Pedestrian accidents are often fatal. Defensive driving and constant vigilance are required.

osha.title: OSHA Basics ‚Äî Workplace Hazards
bullets: Train for your facility's hazards and use the scene hotspots to practice. Control hazards before operating.
Blind corners & aisles: Stop/creep, sound horn, look; use convex mirrors; keep corners clear of parked equipment.
Pedestrians: Marked walkways, eye contact, spotters when required; maintain separation; right-of-way to pedestrians.
Ramps & slopes: Keep forks low/tilted back; no turning on ramps; control speed; chock as needed.
Docks & edges: Use dock locks/chocks; verify dock plates (capacity, lip engaged, dry); maintain a setback from edges; watch overhead doors.
Spills & leaks: Clean or barricade; report leaks; never travel through unidentified liquids.
Speed & visibility: Obey posted speed; maintain lighting; beacon/reverse beeper operating; slow for wet/icy floors.
Overhead obstructions: Verify clearances; never travel with an elevated load; watch sprinklers/doors/fixtures.
Charging/fueling areas: Ventilated, no ignition sources; eyewash/spill kits available and known.

checklist_items.title: Train for your facility's hazards
checklist_items.description: and use the scene hotspots to practice. Control hazards before operating.

details.heading: Workplace-Specific Training (OSHA 1910.178(l)(3)):
details.body: OSHA requires training in operating conditions specific to YOUR workplace. This includes:
items: Surface conditions (wet, uneven, slopes)
Load types and characteristics common to your facility
Traffic patterns and pedestrian zones
Specific hazards unique to your environment

subsections.heading: Hazard Control Hierarchy:
subsections.body: 1. Eliminate hazards if possible | 2. Engineer controls (barriers, guards) | 3. Administrative (policies, training) | 4. PPE as last resort

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Your employer must document site-specific hazards and provide additional training for any unique conditions.

checklist_items.title: Blind corners & aisles
checklist_items.description: Stop/creep, sound horn, look; use convex mirrors; keep corners clear of parked equipment.

details.heading: Blind Corner Procedures:
items: Slow to creep speed as you approach (2-3 mph max)
Sound horn to alert anyone around the corner
Check mirrors if available to see ahead
Edge forward carefully - never commit to a turn without clear view
Listen for other equipment or voices

subsections.heading: Facility Controls:
subsections.body: Convex mirrors should be installed at blind intersections. Keep corners clear of parked equipment, pallets, or boxes. Mark high-traffic intersections with lines or signage.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è T-bone collisions at blind corners can be fatal. Always assume someone is coming.

checklist_items.title: Pedestrians
checklist_items.description: Marked walkways, eye contact, spotters when required; maintain separation; right-of-way to pedestrians.

details.heading: Pedestrian Protection (OSHA 1910.178(l)(1)):
details.body: OSHA requires permanent aisles and passageways be appropriately marked. Pedestrians have absolute right-of-way.
items: Marked walkways: Respect pedestrian-only zones with painted lines
Eye contact: Never pass a pedestrian without making direct eye contact
Spotter required: Congested areas, limited visibility, or when backing long distances
Safe separation: Maintain at least 3 feet clearance when passing workers
Stop and yield: Always give pedestrians right-of-way without exception
details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Pedestrian fatalities are preventable. Treat every person as if they can't see or hear you.

checklist_items.title: Ramps & slopes
checklist_items.description: Keep forks low/tilted back; no turning on ramps; control speed; chock as needed.

details.heading: Ramp and Slope Procedures:

subsections.heading: Load position based on direction:
items: Loaded going uphill: Forks point uphill to prevent load sliding
Unloaded going downhill: Forks point downhill for stability

subsections.heading: Critical Rules for Grades:
items: Keep forks 4-6 inches off surface, mast tilted back
NEVER turn on a ramp - straighten out first, then turn
Descend slowly using service brake, not neutral coasting
Use wheel chocks when loading/unloading on slopes
Watch for surface conditions (wet, icy, loose gravel)

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Tip-overs on ramps are usually lateral (sideways). Never turn while on a grade.

checklist_items.title: Docks & edges
checklist_items.description: Use dock locks/chocks; verify dock plates (capacity, lip engaged, dry); maintain a setback from edges; watch overhead doors.

details.heading: Loading Dock Safety (OSHA 1910.178(k)(1)):
items: Dock locks: Engage restraints before driving onto trailer
Wheel chocks: Place at trailer wheels as backup restraint
Dock plate inspection: Verify capacity rating, lip properly engaged, surface dry and clean
Edge awareness: Maintain 12-inch setback from edges at all times
Communication: Coordinate with dock supervisor and truck driver

subsections.heading: Trailer Safety:
subsections.body: Verify trailer is stable and won't roll. Check floor condition inside trailer - look for holes, weak spots, or damage. Ensure adequate lighting inside trailer. Never enter a trailer if it's moving or unstable.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Trailers creeping away from dock or dock plate failure causes serious accidents. Always verify restraints.

checklist_items.title: Spills & leaks
checklist_items.description: Clean or barricade; report leaks; never travel through unidentified liquids.

details.heading: Spill Response Procedures:
items: Stop operations: Don't drive through spills - creates slip hazard
Barricade immediately: Use cones or caution tape to warn others
Identify substance: Check container labels, ask supervisor
Clean per SDS: Use appropriate absorbent and disposal method
Report all leaks: Document location, substance, and action taken

subsections.heading: Common Hazardous Fluids:
items: Battery acid (sulfuric acid - extremely corrosive)
Hydraulic fluid (slippery, fire hazard if heated)
LP gas (explosion hazard)
Fuel (fire hazard)

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Unidentified liquids may be hazardous. Never attempt cleanup without proper PPE and SDS guidance.

checklist_items.title: Speed & visibility
checklist_items.description: Obey posted speed; maintain lighting; beacon/reverse beeper operating; slow for wet/icy floors.

details.heading: Speed Control (OSHA 1910.178(n)(8)):
details.body: Speed limits must be posted and obeyed. Typical limits are 5-8 mph in open areas, 2-3 mph in congested zones or at intersections.

subsections.heading: Speed Reduction Required:
items: Wet, icy, or oily surfaces (reduce speed 50% or more)
Congested areas with pedestrians
Approaching intersections or blind corners
Uneven surfaces or floor joints
When carrying large or unstable loads

subsections.heading: Visibility Equipment:
subsections.body: Headlights, beacons, and backup alarms must be operational. These devices alert pedestrians to your presence and improve your visibility of the environment.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Speed-related accidents increase in severity. Slower speeds allow more reaction time to avoid collisions.

checklist_items.title: Overhead obstructions
checklist_items.description: Verify clearances; never travel with an elevated load; watch sprinklers/doors/fixtures.

details.heading: Overhead Clearance Verification:
items: Mast height: Know your truck's maximum mast height (extended)
Load height: Add load height to mast height for total clearance needed
Overhead guard clearance: Factor in overhead guard when going under structures
Sprinkler systems: Contact can discharge fire suppression or cause flooding
Door frames: Verify adequate clearance before entering
Electrical conduits: Contact with high-voltage can be fatal

subsections.heading: Safe Practices:
subsections.body: Mark low clearance areas with warning signs and height indicators. Never raise loads higher than necessary for travel. When approaching low clearances, stop and visually verify safe passage.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Striking overhead obstacles can cause load falls, structural damage, or electrocution. Always verify clearance before proceeding.

checklist_items.title: Charging/fueling areas
checklist_items.description: Ventilated, no ignition sources; eyewash/spill kits available and known.

details.heading: Battery Charging Area Requirements (OSHA 1910.178(g)):
items: Ventilation: Adequate to disperse hydrogen gas generated during charging
No smoking: Posted signs prohibiting smoking and open flames
Eyewash station: Within 10 seconds travel time for battery acid exposure
Spill kit: Acid neutralizer and absorbent materials readily available
Fire extinguisher: Class ABC rated, accessible and charged

subsections.heading: LP Fueling Area Requirements:
items: Well-ventilated area (preferably outdoors)
No ignition sources within 20 feet
Cylinder storage must be secure and upright
Fire extinguisher readily available

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Battery acid can cause chemical burns. LP gas is explosive. Know emergency procedures before charging/fueling.

osha.title: OSHA Basics ‚Äî Charging/Fueling & Care
osha.note: Reference: OSHA 29 CFR 1910.178(g), (l); manufacturer manuals; SDS.
bullets: Battery charging: Park, set brake, forks down, power off; ventilated area; no smoking/open flames.
Wear PPE (eye/face, gloves, apron per SDS). Eyewash and spill neutralizer available.
Unplug truck; inspect cables/connectors; connect charger leads correctly; verify charger settings.

checklist_items.title: Battery charging
checklist_items.description: Park, set brake, forks down, power off; ventilated area; no smoking/open flames.

details.heading: Battery Charging Procedures (OSHA 1910.178(g)):

subsections.heading: Before charging:
items: Park in designated charging area with adequate ventilation
Set parking brake and lower forks completely
Turn off truck power (key off, disconnect switch if equipped)
Allow battery to cool if just used

subsections.heading: Area Requirements:
items: Adequate ventilation to disperse hydrogen gas
No smoking or open flame signs posted
Eyewash station within 10 seconds
Spill kit with acid neutralizer available

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Hydrogen gas generated during charging is explosive. One spark can cause battery explosion with acid spray.

checklist_items.title: Wear PPE (eye/face, gloves, apron per SDS)
checklist_items.description: Eyewash and spill neutralizer available.

details.heading: Required PPE for Battery Handling:
items: Face shield or goggles: Full face protection against acid splash
Rubber gloves: Chemical-resistant, extend past wrists
Rubber apron: Protects torso and legs from acid
Safety shoes: Chemical-resistant with toe protection

subsections.heading: Emergency Equipment (OSHA 1910.178(g)(2)):
items: Eyewash station accessible within 10 seconds
Acid neutralizer (baking soda solution) for spills
Absorbent materials for containment
First aid kit with burn treatment supplies

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Battery acid causes severe chemical burns on contact. Know location of safety equipment before handling batteries.

checklist_items.title: Unplug truck
checklist_items.description: inspect cables/connectors; connect charger leads correctly; verify charger settings.

details.heading: Safe Charging Connection Procedure:
items: 1. Unplug truck: Disconnect battery from truck (if removable) or turn off all switches
2. Inspect cables: Check for fraying, exposed wires, damaged insulation, or corrosion
3. Clean connectors: Remove any corrosion or debris from terminals
4. Verify polarity: Match positive to positive, negative to negative
5. Connect charger: Plug charger leads firmly into battery connector
6. Check charger: Verify correct voltage and amperage settings for your battery

subsections.heading: Charger Settings:
subsections.body: Verify charger voltage matches battery (24V, 36V, 48V, etc.). Incorrect settings can damage battery or create fire hazard. Modern chargers auto-detect, but older models require manual selection.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Reversed polarity or wrong voltage can cause battery damage, fire, or explosion. Always verify before starting charge.

checklist_items.title: After charge
checklist_items.description: turn charger off (if required), then disconnect; inspect for heat/damage; keep vent caps in place.

details.heading: Post-Charging Procedures:

subsections.heading: Disconnection sequence:
items: 1. Turn off charger: Stop charging cycle if manual charger
2. Disconnect leads: Remove charger connector from battery
3. Inspect connections: Check for heat damage, melting, or corrosion
4. Check electrolyte: Verify levels (if applicable) - add distilled water only
5. Secure vent caps: Ensure all caps are tightened to prevent acid spray

subsections.heading: Heat and Damage Inspection:
subsections.body: Batteries and connectors get hot during charging. Excessive heat indicates problems - damaged cables, poor connections, or charger malfunction. Report any overheating immediately.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Hot batteries can off-gas more hydrogen. Allow cooling time before use. Never add water immediately after charging.

checklist_items.title: LP fuel (if applicable)
checklist_items.description: Shut engine off; close cylinder valve; allow area to cool; no ignition sources.

details.heading: LP Cylinder Change Procedure (OSHA 1910.178(f)):

subsections.heading: Before removing cylinder:
items: Shut off engine completely
Close cylinder valve (turn clockwise)
Allow engine to burn remaining fuel in lines
Wait for exhaust system to cool (hot surfaces ignite LP)
Park in well-ventilated area away from ignition sources

subsections.heading: Cylinder Removal/Installation:
subsections.body: LP cylinders must be handled upright. Never drop or roll cylinders. Inspect for damage, dents, rust, or leaks before installing. Secure with strap/clamp and locating pin. Leak test connections with soap solution before starting engine.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è LP gas is heavier than air and collects in low areas. If you smell propane (rotten egg odor), evacuate area immediately.

checklist_items.title: Wear PPE; remove/replace cylinder upright
checklist_items.description: with locating pin engaged; secure clamp/strap.

details.heading: LP Cylinder Handling PPE:
items: Safety gloves (protect hands from cold and sharp edges)
Safety glasses or face shield
Steel-toe boots (cylinders are heavy ~35 lbs)

subsections.heading: Proper Cylinder Installation:
items: Keep upright: Never tip or lay cylinders horizontally
Locating pin: Must engage properly to prevent cylinder movement
Secure clamp/strap: Tighten to prevent shifting during operation
Connection: Thread fitting carefully - don't cross-thread
Valve operation: Open slowly (counter-clockwise) after connection

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Improperly secured cylinders can fall off during operation, causing leaks or impact hazards.

checklist_items.title: Reconnect
checklist_items.description: open valve slowly; leak-check; if odor/leak‚Äîshut down and report.

details.heading: Leak Detection Procedures:

subsections.heading: After installing LP cylinder:
items: Open valve slowly: Turn counter-clockwise 1-2 full turns
Soap test: Apply soap solution to all connections
Look for bubbles: Any bubbling indicates a leak
Smell test: LP has added odorant (mercaptan) - smells like rotten eggs

subsections.heading: If Leak Detected:
items: Close cylinder valve immediately
Do NOT attempt to repair - call maintenance
Evacuate area if strong odor present
Tag truck out of service
Report to supervisor

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è NEVER use open flames or matches to check for leaks. LP gas is extremely flammable and forms explosive mixtures.

checklist_items.title: Care & records
checklist_items.description: Only authorized personnel repair/adjust trucks; defective trucks are removed from service.

details.heading: Maintenance Authorization (OSHA 1910.178(q)(1)):
details.body: Only persons trained and authorized by the employer may perform repairs or adjustments to powered industrial trucks. Operators should NEVER attempt repairs.

subsections.heading: Operator Responsibilities:
items: Report all defects immediately to supervisor
Tag out defective equipment to prevent use
Document defects on inspection forms
Never bypass safety devices or make field repairs
Follow lockout/tagout procedures when applicable

subsections.heading: Recordkeeping Requirements (OSHA 1910.178(l)(6)):
subsections.body: Employers must maintain records of operator training including: operator name, training dates, evaluation dates, and identity of persons conducting training and evaluation. Records demonstrate compliance during OSHA inspections.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Unauthorized repairs or modifications can void certifications and create liability for accidents.

checklist_items.title: Operator certification records
checklist_items.description: include name, training date, evaluation date, and trainer/evaluator. Provide refresher training after incidents/unsafe operation/workplace changes, and evaluate each operator at least every 3 years.

details.heading: Certification Requirements (OSHA 1910.178(l)):

subsections.heading: Initial Certification Must Include:
items: Formal instruction (classroom or online)
Practical training (hands-on with equipment)
Evaluation of operator performance in workplace
Training on workplace-specific conditions and equipment

subsections.heading: Refresher Training Required (OSHA 1910.178(l)(4)):
items: Every 3 years minimum - re-evaluate and document
After any accident or near-miss involving the operator
After observed unsafe operation by supervisor
When assigned to new truck type with different characteristics
When workplace conditions change (new hazards, equipment, processes)

subsections.heading: Documentation to Maintain:
subsections.body: Records must include operator name, training dates, evaluation dates, and identity of persons who trained and evaluated the operator. These records prove OSHA compliance.

details.warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Operating without current certification violates OSHA and exposes employer to penalties up to $156,000+ per violation.

practice.title: End-of-shift safety checks
practice.subtitle: Tap each item to review end-of-shift safety
practice.completion_message: You know how to safely end your shift! Never walk away from a forklift without completing shutdown ‚Äî an unsecured truck is a hazard to everyone. (OSHA 1910.178(m))

items.label: Review shutdown procedures
items.tip: Follow the sequence: Neutral ‚Üí Brake ‚Üí Forks down ‚Üí Key off ‚Äî skipping steps creates hazards

items.label: Review attachment safety
items.tip: Attachments must be approved for your truck ‚Äî they change capacity and require data plate update

items.label: Review charging safety protocols
items.tip: Batteries produce explosive hydrogen gas during charging ‚Äî proper ventilation prevents ignition

items.label: Verify charging area is safe (ventilation, no flames)
items.tip: No smoking, open flames, or sparks within 25 feet ‚Äî hydrogen gas is highly explosive

items.label: Check PPE for battery handling
items.tip: Face shield, rubber gloves, and apron required ‚Äî battery acid causes severe burns

items.label: Confirm proper shutdown sequence
items.tip: Neutral, parking brake, forks flat on floor ‚Äî prevents roll-away and trip hazards

items.label: Inspect fuel/power connections
items.tip: Check for leaks, corrosion, and secure connections ‚Äî fuel leaks cause fires, loose cables arc

items.label: Verify parking brake and forks lowered
items.tip: Forks flat on floor prevents tripping ‚Äî parking brake prevents uncontrolled movement

source_ts.back: Neutral ‚Üí Steer straight ‚Üí Parking brake ‚Üí Forks down ‚Üí Key off ‚Üí Connect charger ‚Üí Wheel chock.
